<Link id="l00027" /><CodeLine lineNumber="27" lineLink="/docs/api/groups/llvmcerror/#gaaba79ae56a17485c5d3fbd004ff60e47"><span class="doxyHighlightKeyword">typedef</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> void (&#42;<a href="/docs/api/groups/llvmcerror/#gaaba79ae56a17485c5d3fbd004ff60e47">LLVMFatalErrorHandler</a>)(</span><span class="doxyHighlightKeyword">const</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeywordType">char</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> &#42;Reason);</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00028" /><CodeLine lineNumber="28"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00029" /><CodeLine lineNumber="29"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/&#42;&#42;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00030" /><CodeLine lineNumber="30"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; Install a fatal error handler. By default, if LLVM detects a fatal error, it</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00031" /><CodeLine lineNumber="31"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; will call exit(1). This may not be appropriate in many contexts. For example,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00032" /><CodeLine lineNumber="32"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; doing exit(1) will bypass many crash reporting/tracing system tools. This</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00033" /><CodeLine lineNumber="33"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; function allows you to install a callback that will be invoked prior to the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00034" /><CodeLine lineNumber="34"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; call to exit(1).</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00035" /><CodeLine lineNumber="35"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42;/</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00036" /><CodeLine lineNumber="36"><span class="doxyHighlightKeywordType">void</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> <a href="/docs/api/groups/llvmcerror/#gaf6159e6764fb23072ec25514b90b0ebd">LLVMInstallFatalErrorHandler</a>(<a href="/docs/api/groups/llvmcerror/#gaaba79ae56a17485c5d3fbd004ff60e47">LLVMFatalErrorHandler</a> Handler);</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00037" /><CodeLine lineNumber="37"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00038" /><CodeLine lineNumber="38"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/&#42;&#42;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00039" /><CodeLine lineNumber="39"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; Reset the fatal error handler. This resets LLVM&#39;s fatal error handling</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00040" /><CodeLine lineNumber="40"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; behavior to the default.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00041" /><CodeLine lineNumber="41"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42;/</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00042" /><CodeLine lineNumber="42"><span class="doxyHighlightKeywordType">void</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> <a href="/docs/api/groups/llvmcerror/#ga7ea3d621a4b178b39e068f2c017ae617">LLVMResetFatalErrorHandler</a>(</span><span class="doxyHighlightKeywordType">void</span><span class="doxyHighlight">);</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00043" /><CodeLine lineNumber="43"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00044" /><CodeLine lineNumber="44"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/&#42;&#42;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00045" /><CodeLine lineNumber="45"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; Enable LLVM&#39;s built-in stack trace code. This intercepts the OS&#39;s crash</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00046" /><CodeLine lineNumber="46"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; signals and prints which component of LLVM you were in at the time if the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00047" /><CodeLine lineNumber="47"><span class="doxyHighlightComment"> &#42; crash.</span></CodeLine>
